idCitation.resTitle: 2015 Place Points for the American Community Survey

dataIdInfo.idPurp: This file is provided by IPUMS NHGIS to depict the point location of all incorporated and Census-designated places available in the 2015 American Community Survey data. Each point represents the location of a place for which the U.S. Census Bureau tabulated and published data.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This file depicts the location of incorporated and Census-designated places as identified in the 2015 American Community Survey data. It matches places in both the 1-year and 5-year data sets. The file was created at the University of Minnesota for IPUMS NHGIS project (https://www.nhgis.org).

The points in this file are derived from boundary files from the National Historical Geographic Information System (IPUMS NHGIS), which are in turn based on the U.S. Census Bureau's 2015 TIGER/Line files, with coastal water areas erased. Incorporated and Census-designated place points were snapped to populated place points from the U.S. Geological Survey's Geographic Names Information System (GNIS -- https://geonames.usgs.gov/domestic/).

This shapefile is part of a series created by IPUMS NHGIS. The series consists of shapefiles for the twelve decennial censuses taken between 1990 and 2010 and the seven American Community Survey datasets published between 2009 and 2015.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: The primary source of funding for this shapefiles is the National Science Foundation (NSF), grant SES-1324875. Additional support has been provided by the Minnesota Population Center (NIH, HD-04023).

Consts.useLimit:
No fee may be charged for use or distribution of these data. Publications and research reports based on these data must cite it appropriately:

Steven Manson, Jonathan Schroeder, David Van Riper, and Steven Ruggles. IPUMS National Historical Geographic Information System: Version 12.0 [Database]. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota. 2017. http://doi.org/10.18128/D050.V12.0

For policy briefs or articles in teh population press that use the IPUMS NHGIS database, we recommend that you cite the use of IPUMS NHGIS data as follows:

IPUMS NHGIS, University of Minnesota, https://www.nhgis.org

The licensing agreement for use of IPUMS NHGIS data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography at https://bibliography.ipums.org/.

themeKeys.keyword: 2011-2015 American Community Survey, ACS, incorporated places, Census-designated places, IPUMS NHGIS, IPUMS, GNIS

placeKeys.keyword: United States of America, USA, United States

LegConsts.othConsts: All persons are granted a limited license to use and distribute this documentation and the available data, subject to the use constrants.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of state or state equivalent.

Nationally unique text code for each state, matching values given in IPUMS NHGIS data tables and boundary files. The NHGIS state code is the two character FIPS code with a '0' or other value appended. States or territories currently in existence have a '0' at the end of the code. States or territories that no longer exist have a value other than '0' at the end of the code.
Name of incorporated or Census-designated place.
Name of incorporated or Census-designated place.

Nationally unique text code for each incorporated or Census-designated place. NHGISPLACE codes begin 'G' to ensure that GIS and spreadsheet software interprets the value as text, not numbers, which preserves leading zeroes. The 'G' is followed by the NHGIS state code (which is the FIPS code with a '0' appended), followed by a six-character code. The six-character code uniquely identifies a place within a year, and it can be used to link place points together across time. Points with the same NHGISPLACE code in different years represent the same incorporated or Census-designated place, even if the name or boundary has changed.
Vintage of the boundaries or maps used to create the points.

Nationally unique code for each point, combining values given by the NHGISST variable, a 'G' (to ensure that GIS and spreadsheet software interprets the value as text, not numbers), and a five-character FIPS code. The GISJOIN field may be used to join Census or American Community Survey data of the same vintage as the point (e.g., 2015 ACS data may be joined to the 2015 place points using their shared GISJOIN field).

dataLineage.statement:
We converted IPUMS NHGIS place boundary files for 1980, 1990, 2000, 2010, and 2012 to geographic centroids and then merged the centroid datasets. We removed points with duplicate names and GISJOINs, yielding a dataset that contained a single point for each unique place that existed between 1980 and 2012.
We then joined the point dataset to the NHGIS Time Series Table (TST) for places. The TST tells us the years (1970-2012) in which each place existed. Since we already had points for 1980-2012, this join served two purposed. First, point records that matched the TST records could be extended back to 1970. Second, TST records that failed to match the point dataset were places that we needed to add to the point dataset. All of the unmatched TST records existed only in 1970 and had no match because there were no GIS data for 1970. were from the 1970 census. We added points representing the unmatched records using a combination of GNIS data and published census maps. At the end of this step, we had a complete record of place points matched to census data from 1970-2012.
We then joined the centroids to the populated place points from the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) database using a combination of place, county, and state names. The GNIS points are typically stable across time and are located at or near the historical, functional place center (e.g., the central business district of a large city). For matched records, we moved the coordinates from the geographic center of the place to the GNIS location. For unmatched records with an NHGIS place centroid, we continued using the geographic centroid. Finally, for unmatched records without an NHGIS place centroid, we used a combination of GNIS points and scanned, georeferenced 1970 Census Bureau maps to create the place points.
After we completed our 1970-2012 dataset, we developed a process for locating and identifying incorporated and unincorporated places for 1930-1960. For the decennial censuses from 1930-1960, the U.S. Census Bureau published volumes that contained lists of incorporated and unincorporated places and maps that depicted the locations of these places. We georeferenced the maps to NHGIS county boundaries and then overlaid the point dataset on the georeferenced maps. Then, we compared the point dataset to the list of places. We based our comparison on place names. If there was a match, we flagged the point as existing in the year we were examining. Finally, for the places on the list that did not match the point dataset, we used the georeferenced map, in conjunction with the GNIS data, to create a point feature. If we found a point in GNIS, we snapped our new point to it. If we failed to find a point in GNIS, we placed a point in the center of the place as depicted on the map. We then added the place name to that point and flagged it as existing. We worked on a state-by-state basis and completed an entire year's worth of places before moving onto another year. We started in 1960 and worked backwards to 1930.
After finishing the 1930 place points, we developed a process for locating and identifying incorporated and unincorporated places for the earlier censuses. The Census Bureau first published maps showing the locations of places in 1930. For earlier censuses, we only have lists of places from the printed volumes. We compared the point dataset to the list of places based on names. If we found a match, we flagged the point as existing in the year we were examining. Places listed in the census volumes but not in the point dataset were created using a combination of GNIS data, published footnotes in the census volumes, and web search to ascertain their location. We used this process for the 1900-1920 place points.
We then QA/QC'ed the point dataset, comparing it against the Census Bureau's published lists of places. This process caught listed places that we not captured in the GIS data.
Next, we created a new six-character unique identifier for all place points in the data series. For points that have a modern five-digit FIPS code, we re-used the FIPS code and appended a '0' to the end. For points without a modern five-digit FIPS code, we developed a two-step process to create their six-digit code. First, we created five-digit codes, maintaining alphabetical order for all places in the data series. Second, we appended a '5' to the end of the newly-created five-digit codes. This '5' suffix indicates that the place no longer exists, and it did not exist long enough to receive a five-digit FIPS code. For example, a record for Minneapolis, Minnesota, is in every year-specific file from 1900-2012. It has a FIPS code of '43000' and an NHGISPLACE code of '430000'. New Paynesville, Minnesota, is only in the 1900 dataset. Its new five digit code is '45781' was created by calculating a value between existing FIPS codes for the places alphabetically before and after 'New Paynesville'. The '5' suffix was then added to create an six-character code of '457815'. Finally, we created a ten-digit NHGISPLACE code by concatenating the six-character code with the three-character NHGIS state identifier and a 'G'.
The last step of the process was to add in place data from the 2009, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015 American Community Survey datasets. When we finished adding the new data, we had a data series from 1900-2015 that depict the locations of incorporated and unincorporated places listed in data published by the U.S. Census Bureau.
There are two ways to use the NHGIS place point shapefiles. For 1970-2015, you may download population and housing characteristics from NHGIS and joinng them to the year-specific shapefiles using the GISJOIN field. If you want to know the years for which the Census Bureau has information for a given place, you may join the year-specific shapefiles using the NHGISPLACE code.
